channel.title: What should I do? [iPhone 4S]
channel.description:
I'm on my 3rd iphone 4S since release day, it's now broken again... I have arranged another appointment to get it fixed but I keep wasting lots of time going into the shop and getting it replaced plus on my screen protectors.
I keep getting the "SIM Failure" messages, Its nothing to do with my carrier or SIM as it works in other phones. I have a meeting with the "Genius Bar" on Tuesday, it's an actual joke really when I paid £600 for the phone.

item.title: What should I do? [iPhone 4S]
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Pwnd, post:18, topic:422299”][quote author=eczema3 link=topic=524970.msg3821389#msg3821389 date=1321812920]

I’d get an Android phone.

You do realise to get an Android phone which has the same sort of specs you’d actually have to spend MORE than you would have on the equivalent iPhone…?
[/quote]You do realize you don’t know what you’re talking about :P[/quote]

I guess he doesn’t, as he still hasn’t replied to my post.

Read full topic

item.description:

The Galaxy Nexus is more expensive than the iPhone 4S here, but only by around £20

Read full topic

item.title: What should I do? [iPhone 4S]
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

The Galaxy Nexus is more expensive than the iPhone 4S here, but only by around £20, which for the higher spec hardware you get on the Galaxy Nexus is justified. Other than the more expensive materials for the phone’s structure on the iPhone (which aren’t all that practical), there isn’t much that should mean the iPhone should be priced at what it is, but you know how it is. It’s the Apple tax.

If the Nexus wasn’t an ICS device (I’ve been very, very impressed with what they’re doing with ICS), I’d pay extra for the iPhone for iOS, the ecosystem, in my opinion in is still far ahead of Android’s, but with the new focus on design consistency, and efforts to encourage developers to work to a certain philosophy, instead of doing whatever the fuck they want, I’d be willing to give it a go.

But pre 4.0, I wouldn’t. We have two Android devices in the house at the moment, one on 2.3 and one on 2.2, they’re a big step back from iOS.

Read full topic

item.title: What should I do? [iPhone 4S]
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

What about the Samsung Galaxy Nexus i9250? (sorry for fucked up table)

            iPhone 4S 16GB		Galaxy Nexus i9250

Price € 645 € 565 *
Internal storage 16GB 16GB
Processor 1GHz 1.2GHz*
SD card No Yes*
Screendiagonal 3,5" 4,65"*
Resolution 960x640 1280x720*
Screen LCD Super Amoled
Memory 512MB 1GB*

So out of these 8 criteria, the Samsung ‘wins’ 6, one is a tie and one I can’t judge because I don’t know how a Super Amoled compares to an LCD screen. The processor is won by the Samsung, but clock frequency isn’t everything so that might be subject of debate too. But still.

So what functionality does the iPhone 4S have, that justifies the difference of €80,-?

Read full topic

item.title: What should I do? [iPhone 4S]
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

I’d get an Android phone.

The problem probably is the combination of the phone and your SIM, so if you really want the phone then obviously you should get a new SIM card. The cause lies with the phone though. You’d expect a £600 phone to be compatible with a SIM card that isn’t from the stone age.

Read full topic
